Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Role of Insulators in linking Gene Regulation and Nuclear Organization

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Chromosome organization and chromatin dynamics play important roles in nuclear processes such as gene regulation. However, understanding of most mechanisms that link nuclear organization to function remains rudimentary. Chromatin domain insulators (also called boundary elements) might link gene regulation to nuclear organization. Insulators are thought to partition chromosomes into functionally independent domains, preventing cross-talk so that genes in adjacent domains can be differentially regulated. But little is known about molecular mechanisms by which insulators function. The goal of this research project is to gain insight into molecular mechanisms by focusing on a particular insulator-binding protein in Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies), the Boundary Element-Associated Factor, BEAF. Various approaches will be used to identify important domains in BEAF, and to identify proteins that interact with BEAF. The relationship of these proteins to BEAF will then be characterized. Previous results from the laboratory of the PI found that BEAF usually binds adjacent to promoters and plays a role in keeping the associated promoters active. Experiments will be performed to determine if promoter activity correlates with BEAF-dependent insulator activity, and to determine if interacting proteins affect BEAF-associated promoter activity. Some models of insulator function hypothesize that insulators are involved in nuclear organization by mediating the formation of chromatin loops. There is evidence that BEAF mediates chromatin loop formation. To explore this in more depth, networks of looping interactions will be determined for six BEAF binding regions using circular chromosome conformation capture (4C) assays with high throughput DNA sequencing. The proportion of loop partners that are insulators, promoters, enhancers, or other sequences will be determined, as will the distances over which looping occurs. Results will be validated by two-color fluorescence in situ hybridization and chromosome conformation capture (3C) assays. Identification of interaction partners of BEAF and the role of BEAF and these proteins in promoter activity will provide insight into molecular mechanisms of insulator function. The looping experiments address the role of insulators in nuclear organization. Together, these experiments will provide insight into the relationship between nuclear organization and gene regulation.

Broader impacts: An integral goal of research in the lab of the PI is to train the next generation of scientists. Participants in this research project will include both graduate and undergraduate students, including members of traditionally underrepresented groups. At least two undergraduates usually work in the lab each semester and in the summer. They participate in cloning, PCR (mutagenesis, sequencing, inverse PCR to localize transgene insertion sites), fly genetics, microscopy, and protein biochemistry. Most have been females, minorities or both. Several have gone on to careers in medicine or life sciences research. The PI has also served as a local Science Fair judge, mentored two high school science fair projects, and is recruiting another high school student. One project won second place in its category in statewide competition. PhD students and associated undergraduates will be trained during this project. The research will enhance teaching by the PI of junior and senior level molecular cell biology courses, and of a graduate seminar course entitled Chromatin, Nuclear Organization and Gene Expression developed by the PI based on his research expertise. Research results will be disseminated at conferences and by publication. The PI will continue to make reagents developed in his laboratory, such as fly stocks, available to the research community. Thus this research will have significant scientific and educational impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to study the Drosophila melanogaster Boundary Element-Associated Factor (BEAF) as a model for understanding how chromatin domain insulator proteins contribute to gene regulation and the architectural organization of chromosomes in nuclei. This is important because faulty organization can affect gene regulation and lead to developmental defects and disease. There were three specific aims. Two were concerned with getting at molecular mechanisms of BEAF function by identifying partner proteins and studying their relationship to BEAF. The third aim was to examine the role of BEAF in nuclear organization by using Circular Chromosome Conformation Capture (4C) to identify chromosomal looping interactions made by select BEAF binding regions to other chromosomal regions. This project resulted in three publications with three more in preparation. It also laid the foundation for future studies examining the relationship between BEAF and additional identified partner proteins.

 

The first aim identified proteins that physically interact with BEAF using a yeast 2-hybrid (Y2H) screen. Later, proteomic mass spectrometry was used to identify proteins that co-immunoprecipitated with epitope-tagged BEAF from Drosophila nuclear protein extracts. Other methods were used to confirm interactions with potential partner proteins. Y2H and other methods were also used to characterize how BEAF interacts with itself, and whether the self-interaction domain or other parts of BEAF interact with different partner proteins. Attention was focused on the few transcription factors and a chromatin remodeling complex subunit identified by Y2H. These proteins were of particular interest because genome-wide mapping of BEAF binding found that it usually binds near gene promoters. Additional transcription factors and additional subunits of the chromatin remodeling complex were found by mass spectrometry. Evidence of a role for BEAF in transcription activation, including by interaction with transcription factors, was found. Evidence for functional significance of the chromatin remodeling complex interaction was significant but weaker. Likely explanations are that other proteins bound in promoter regions can also recruit chromatin remodeling complexes, and that other families of chromatin remodeling complexes can also be recruited. Following up on these results and investigating the relationship to BEAF of other chromatin proteins identified will be important for understanding mechanisms of gene regulation.

 

The second aim used a model BEAF-dependent insulator element to identify minimal DNA sequences needed for insulator activity. This insulator also contains a promoter, so sequences needed for promoter activity were also determined. BEAF usually binds near promoters, but the relationship between insulator and promoter activity had never been explored. DNA sequences required for both insulator and promoter activity overlapped by 110 base pairs (bp), and included the BEAF binding site. But insulator activity required an additional 50 bp downstream of this region while promoter activity required an additional 50 bp upstream. Attempts to detect and identify proteins in addition to BEAF that bind to the DNA were not successful. Nevertheless, these results demonstrated that BEAF plays a role in both insulator and promoter activity but these activities are distinct. An important future goal is to identify the shared proteins as well as the unique proteins that confer either insulator or promoter activity, in order to get at molecular mechanisms.

 

The third aim used 4C and fluorescence in situ hybridization to study long-range looping interactions within and between chromosomes, with select BEAF binding regions as the viewpoints for these interactions. The results point to principles of long-distance interactions made by active chromatin. They support a previously proposed model in which condensed chromatin is sticky and associates into topologically associating domains (TADs) separated by active chromatin. The highly variable long-distance interactions of the BEAF viewpoints are likely driven by redundant factors that open chromatin to promote transcription, combined with active chromatin filling spaces between TADs while packing of TADs relative to each other varies from cell to cell.

 

During this work, graduate and undergraduate students and a high school student were trained in laboratory techniques, the scientific method and critical thinking. This includes individuals from underrepresented groups. Two graduate students earned PhDs, and three others are nearly finished. Most undergraduates who work in my lab go on to continue their education, often at a medical school and sometimes in a graduate program. The high school student is interested in earning a PhD and pursuing a research career in biology. Hopefully her experience in my lab will reinforce this goal. Graduate students are assisting with mentoring of undergraduates and the high school student. Thus they are also gaining mentoring experience.

 

By identifying proteins that function with BEAF, we are contributing to the understanding of how chromatin domain insulators work. This impacts our understanding of gene regulation and the role of nuclear organization in gene regulation. In the future, this understanding could contribute to controlling gene regulation in applications such as gene therapy, biopharmaceutical production, agriculture and basic research.
